entry.title: Value Mappings Not Applied During Simulation (LTMOM) - Direct Transfer ECC to S/4HANA
entry.content:
Problem Description: I'm working on a Direct Transfer scenario from SAP ECC to S/4HANA 2023 using Migration Cockpit with a custom migration object, but the value mappings are not being applied during simulation.

Environment Setup:

  • Source: SAP ECC
  • Target: S/4HANA 2023
  • DMIS component installed and RFC connection configured between systems
  • Custom migration object created using LTMOM with custom function module for data creation

Issue Details:
I have created value mappings for three fields to transform values between source and target systems:

  • Company Code (BUKRS) - Mapping: Z_MAP_BUKRS
  • House Bank (HBKID) - Mapping: Z_MAP_HBKID
  • Bank Account (HKTID) - Mapping: Z_MAP_HKTID

Current Configuration:

  • All three value mappings are properly defined in the migration object structure
  • Field mappings are configured with option "Fill field using a mapping, fixed value or source code rule"
  • Importing parameters are assigned correctly (e.g., IV_HBKID filled with source value)
  • The mappings appear in the "Using this API automatically fills these mapping value rules" section
  • Mapping tasks are successfully generated and show as "Done: 3" in the Migration Cockpit

Problem: During simulation, the migration object processes records using the original source values instead of the mapped target values.

For example:

  • Source company code: 0001
  • Mapped target company code: 1000
  • Expected behavior: Simulation should use company code 1000
  • Actual behavior: Simulation uses company code 0001

Screenshots Attached:

  1. Migration object structure showing value mappings (Z_MAP_BUKRS, Z_MAP_HBKID, Z_MAP_HKTID)
  2. Field mapping configuration for HBKID with importing parameter IV_HBKID
  3. Target API settings showing Z_MAP_BUKRS in automatic mapping rules
  4. Migration Cockpit monitoring showing mapping tasks completed but simulation errors

Question: What configuration am I missing to ensure value mappings are applied during the simulation phase in a custom migration object with Direct Transfer? Are there additional settings required in the custom function module or transfer step configuration?

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: Re: Pass select-options by reference
entry.content:
Nothing to add to the excellent answer by @holm, except that if you don't need to change the value from your class, you may use IMPORTING instead of CHANGING.

If your question is to define your method parameter as TYPE REF TO the SELECT-OPTIONS field, you may use ASSIGN in the report and pass the field symbol instead of S_TIMPER[]. This solution is less elegant and longer.

Here's the code with the solutions:

DATA time_period TYPE d.

SELECT-OPTIONS s_timper FOR time_period NO-EXTENSION.
PARAMETERS by_chang TYPE string.
PARAMETERS by_impor TYPE string.
PARAMETERS by_refer TYPE string.

CLASS class DEFINITION FINAL
  CREATE PRIVATE.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    TYPES period_range TYPE RANGE OF d.

    DATA ref_period_range TYPE REF TO period_range READ-ONLY.

    CLASS-METHODS by_changing
      CHANGING !period       TYPE period_range
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO class.

    CLASS-METHODS by_importing
      IMPORTING !period       TYPE period_range
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO class.

    CLASS-METHODS by_reference
      IMPORTING !period       TYPE REF TO period_range
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO class.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS class IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD by_changing.
    result = NEW class( ).
    result->ref_period_range = REF #( period ) ##NEEDED.
    result->ref_period_range->* = VALUE #( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = sy-datum ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD by_importing.
    result = NEW class( ).
    " READ ONLY
    result->ref_period_range = REF #( period ) ##NEEDED.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD by_reference.
    result = NEW class( ).
    result->ref_period_range = period ##NEEDED.
    DATA(lv_date) = VALUE #( result->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ]-low OPTIONAL ).
    result->ref_period_range->* = VALUE #(
        ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = CONV d( lv_date + 1 ) ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

LOAD-OF-PROGRAM.
  DATA(by_changing) = class=>by_changing( CHANGING period = s_timper[] ).

  DATA(by_importing) = class=>by_importing( period = s_timper[] ).

  FIELD-SYMBOLS <ls_timper> TYPE class=>period_range.
  ASSIGN s_timper[] TO <ls_timper>.
  DATA(by_reference) = class=>by_reference( period = REF #( <ls_timper> ) ).

AT SELECTION-SCREEN OUTPUT.
  by_chang = VALUE #( by_changing->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).
  by_impor = VALUE #( by_importing->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).
  by_refer = VALUE #( by_reference->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).

entry.title: MP: exception caught with cause com.sap.engine.services.jndi.persistent.exceptions720.Namespac in PI
entry.content:

Even though message delivery is successful, this exception still appears and causes the user to see a 500 Internal Server Error.

Could you please advise what could cause this..

entry.title: CP/NP don't work for IN with a tables range of type D, T or N
entry.content:
If you run this code with CP, you can see that the date 20250101 doesn't match the ranges table I CP 20250101:

TYPES tr_date TYPE RANGE OF d.
ASSERT abap_false = xsdbool( EXACT d( '20250101' ) IN
                    VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ) ).

Is there any official documentation of this behavior?

NB: I know that I can use the equivalent condition I EQ 20250101, which works as expected, my question is just about the documentation for CP/NP for IN with a tables range of type D or T.

Thank you.

Sandra

ABAP version: 7.52 SP 0. It's probably the same for all ABAP versions.

References to the ABAP Keyword documentation:

  • rel_exp - Tabular Comparison Operator IN | ABAP Keyword Documentation (IN)
  • rel_exp - Comparison Operators for Character-Like Data Types | ABAP Keyword Documentation (CP, NP)

For your information, you may refer to these results below, including EQ, CP, NP and ranges table of type C(8) and C(6) instead of D and T, and also the single operators CP and NP without IN (the test method succeeds):

CLASS test DEFINITION FINAL
  FOR TESTING RISK LEVEL HARMLESS DURATION SHORT.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS abap_behavior FOR TESTING RAISING cx_static_check.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS test IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD abap_behavior.
    TYPES tr_numc TYPE RANGE OF syspono.
    DATA(lr_numc) = VALUE tr_numc( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '0000000001' ) ).
    DATA(lv_numc) = EXACT syspono( '0000000001' ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_numc IN lr_numc ) ).

    TYPES tv_date_c TYPE c LENGTH 8.
    TYPES tv_time_c TYPE c LENGTH 6.
    TYPES tr_date_c TYPE RANGE OF tv_date_c.
    TYPES tr_time_c TYPE RANGE OF tv_time_c.
    TYPES tr_date   TYPE RANGE OF d.
    TYPES tr_time   TYPE RANGE OF t.
    TYPES tr_dats   TYPE RANGE OF dats.
    TYPES tr_tims   TYPE RANGE OF tims.

    DATA(lv_date) = EXACT d( '20250101' ).
    DATA(lv_time) = EXACT t( '235959' ).

    DATA(lr_date_eq) = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_date_eq_c) = VALUE tr_date_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_dats_eq) = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '20250101' ) ).

    DATA(lr_time_eq) = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_time_eq_c) = VALUE tr_time_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_tims_eq) = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_eq_c ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_eq_c ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_eq ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_eq ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_eq ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_eq ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE D AND T, CP SHOULD BE TRUE BUT ARE FALSE, IS IT DOCUMENTED?
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_cp) = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_dats_cp) = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ).

    DATA(lr_time_cp) = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_tims_cp) = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_cp ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_cp ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE C, CP WORKS
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_cp_c) = VALUE tr_date_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_time_cp_c) = VALUE tr_time_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_cp_c ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_cp_c ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE D AND T, NP SHOULD BE FALSE BUT ARE TRUE, IS IT DOCUMENTED?
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_np) = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_dats_np) = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '20250101' ) ).

    DATA(lr_time_np) = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_tims_np) = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_np ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_np ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_np ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_np ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE C, NP WORKS
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_np_c) = VALUE tr_date_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_time_np_c) = VALUE tr_time_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_np_c ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_np_c ) ).

    " NB: WITHOUT RANGES TABLES, CP BEHAVES AS EXPECTED
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time = '235959' ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date = '20250101' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time CP '2359++' ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date CP '2025*' ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: How to calculate CU consumption and cost for a specific table in SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
I want to understand how to estimate the Capacity Unit (CU) usage and monthly cost for a specific table stored in SAP Datasphere / SAP HANA Cloud.

For example, I have a table with the following details

  • Size On Disk (MiB)
    0.76
    Size In-Memory (MiB)
    0.6
    Number of Records
    5844
     
    Time Table
     
    SAP.TIME.M_TIME_DIMENSION

I‚Äôm trying to determine:

  1. How to calculate the CU consumption per hour and per month for this table.

  2. How to convert the CU usage into cost, using the standard pricing (e.g., 1 CU = USD 0.87 per month).

  3. Whether compute memory or storage contributes more to the total CU usage.

  4. If there is an official formula or documentation for calculating CU at a per-table level.

What is the recommended method or formula for estimating CU consumption and cost for an individual table in SAP Datasphere?

entry.title: Re: CP/NP don't work for IN with a tables range of type D, T or N
entry.content:
I don't have access to ABAP any more  but I guess, the reason is that the behavior of CP after IN is as follows:

 

operand {CP|NP} range_tab-low && range_tab-high

https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abenlogexp_select_option.htm

That means, range_tab-high, containing 00000000 or blanks  in your case, is implicitly concatenated behind range_tab-low and thus the comparison returns false.

entry.title: Is Integration Architecture EA discipline‚Äì or how do we see it?
entry.content:
I did talk on a high-level on integrations and EA in past (my article in SAP EA Community: Enterprise Architecture for integration? ). Recently I‚Äôve also published a Blog in the SAP Community about integrations and EA (Integrations as part of the SAP LeanIX (Enterprise) Architecture?) ‚Äì using SAP LeanIX solutions[1] EAM as a tool of choice. 

It‚Äôs not the first time I talk about integrations, and definitely not the first time I talk about EA‚Ä¶ Somehow, I see some of the statements I made were a bit controversial on the level of EA and TOGAF¬©[2]. 

But why?

Where is Integration Architecture in TOGAF?

‚Ä¶ Of I should not even ask this question?

When we model EA in our EAM solution, where do we place our Integration Architecture? Strictly speaking, if we look at TOGAF there is no Integration Architecture domain ‚Äì it‚Äôs a layer cross all domains ‚Äì it‚Äôs everywhere, right? Or, it‚Äôs only a part of the SBBs? Or some would even say, wait, maybe its part of D. Technology Architecture ‚Äì after all integrations are often observed as ‚Äútechnology‚Äù only‚Ä¶

And this is what I fear ‚Äì if we observe integrations as part of everything, and nothing ‚Äì if we detach integration from strategy (and yes there is Integration Strategy as well) ‚Äì where do we go? If we are only solutioning as per need of Business Processes, or Applications or Data Objects ‚Äì are we in fact consciously pushing integration into silo and ad-hoc solutioning?

Look. we want to apply some Principles in Integration Architecture; like Reuse Policy, Integration Patterns, Integration Use-Cases, Integration Governance etc. How can we build and enforce Integration Strategy, if we are not granted ‚Äúdomain‚Äù (or similar) level?

But, TOGAF is flexible, and nothing is ‚Äúcarved-in-stone‚Äù‚Ä¶ We can tailor TOGAF per our needs‚Ä¶ Is this controversial? Shouldn‚Äôt be.

Integration Service or Interface

What I usually refer as Integration Service, can pretty good match with Interface Fact Sheet in SAP LeanIX[3].

In this respect, Integration Architecture should be observed at the same level as (or as part of) Application and Data Architecture.

  • Application ‚Äúprovides‚Äù and/or ‚Äúconsumes‚Äù.
  • Interface ‚Äútransfers‚Äù Data Object.
  • Interface ‚Äúuses‚Äù IT Component.
  • Initiative ‚Äúaffects‚Äù Interface.

Integration Architecture is the enable for the Business Architecture, just as Technology Architecture is an enabler for the Integration Architecture.

Integration Services are not just dots or lines ‚Äì it‚Äôs much more!, We need to raise the awareness and change the mindset(s) ‚Äì proper integration modeling and design is the key for the success in many initiatives ‚Äì and proper modeling has to come as a result of the Integration Strategy, not just "technical" solutioning on case-to-case basis (silo and ad-hoc).

Let‚Äôs just consider how many projects failed or were delayed because integrations were not properly designed or implemented? And this (usually) has nothing to do with ‚Äúbad‚Äù integration developers and integration engineers‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs (usually) associated with ‚Äúlack‚Äù of Integration Strategy and its governance.

Does this resonate?

Tailoring TOGAF with SAP LeanIX

Yes, I am saying TOGAF, not SAP EAF (Enterprise Architecture Framework)[4], just to be more generalist‚Ä¶ And still, I am here being very pragmatic ‚Äì trying to explain real uses cases ‚Äì putting theoretical framework into practical EAM tool.

Certain mapping is quite obvious, but of course things are not really 1 on 1:

  • B. Business Architecture in TOGAF can easily map with Business Architecture in SAP LeanIX.
  • C. Information System Architecture in TOGAF, can also easily map with Application and Data Architecture in SAP LeanIX
  • D. Technology Architecture in TOGAF seems to be mapping with Technical Architecture in SAP LeamIX.
  • What we see is Strategy & Transformation in SAP LeanIX may be mapped with several phased of TOGAF ADM. I.e. Initiative could probably see somewhere between E. Opportunities and Solution and F. Migration Planning in TOGAF.

But this is only at a high level. Let us be absolutely clear ‚Äì SAP LeanIX does not produce TOGAF style of artifacts. I wouldn‚Äôt say this is because SAP LeanIX is intended to be used only with SAP EAF ‚Äì I see SAP LeanIX as EAM tool, which is not bounded with only one specific EA framework‚Ä¶ Now, none of this is a problem at all, framework is a framework ‚Äì not a rule book, and then again EAM is just a tool, and each tool has its specifics.

Final thoughts

I‚Äôve already given credit to Integration Services in many articles; I‚Äôve already shared my thoughts about importance of proper modeling of the Integration Services ‚Äì and I‚Äôve also shared my thoughts that Integration Architecture should also be recognized on the level of EA.

Of course, those are only my thoughts... 

Check out my other articles (in SAP Community)  and all other articles in SAP Community and SAP EA Community

References

[1] SAP LeanIX: https://www.leanix.net/en/

[2] TOGAF: https://www.opengroup.org/togaf

[3] SAP LeanIX Modeling Guidelines: https://help.sap.com/docs/leanix/ea/fact-sheet-modeling-guidelines

[4] SAP EAF: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-blog-posts/sap-enterprise-architecture-framework/ba-p/124037

entry.title: Re: CP/NP don't work for IN with a tables range of type D or T
entry.content:
Oooooooooooh, thank you very much, that must be the documentation I was looking for! You're right, it works exactly how it is described. If I force the HIGH field to spaces, it works as expected (see code below).

If I may ask, any idea what's behind the use of HIGH for CP and NP?

Demonstration with HIGH date = forced to spaces:

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE D AND T, HIGH must be set to all spaces to make CP and NP work.
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA lv_date_as_spaces TYPE d.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS <lv_date_as_spaces> TYPE c.
    ASSIGN lv_date_as_spaces TO <lv_date_as_spaces> CASTING.
    <lv_date_as_spaces> = ''.
    lr_date_cp = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' high = lv_date_as_spaces ) ).
    lr_dats_cp = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' high = lv_date_as_spaces ) ).

    DATA lv_time_as_spaces TYPE t.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS <lv_time_as_spaces> TYPE c.
    ASSIGN lv_time_as_spaces TO <lv_time_as_spaces> CASTING.
    <lv_time_as_spaces> = ''.
    lr_time_cp = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' high = lv_time_as_spaces ) ).
    lr_tims_cp = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' high = lv_time_as_spaces ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_cp ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_cp ) ).

Edit: consequently, CP/NP don't work with the N type too.

entry.title: Learning Journey progress is not being updated /continuous error message
entry.content:

entry.title: Mvt type 601 does not check the minimum remaining shelf life, whereas 602 does perform this check.
entry.content:
In the configuration path: ‚ÄãIMG -> Logistics Execution -> Warehouse Management -> Inventory Management -> Inventory Posting -> Core Inventory -> Set Expiration Date Check, set the "‚ÄãCheck SL expiration date: 1 Entry and Check‚Äã" for both movement types ‚Äã601‚Äã and ‚Äã602‚Äã and save the configuration.

However, when executing a goods issue (Movement Type 601), the system does not check the material's minimum remaining shelf life, allowing materials with a remaining life below the threshold to be issued normally. Conversely, when reversing this specific goods issue (Movement Type 602), the system reports an error: "‚ÄãCurrent item (30 days) lacks X days of remaining storage time‚Äã", triggers a check for the minimum shelf life, and blocks the reversal operation if the remaining life is insufficient

entry.title: Re: Learning email notification logo to be uploaded
entry.content:
Hi @bharathprakas269 ,

I find it much better to encode you Logo into base64-encoded strings and  then adding the code to your notifications and Certificates.  A good website to do this encoding is:

www.base64-image.de/

Then you just add the following text to your html code for the image:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,{LOGO_base64_Encoded_Code_Here!}" alt="ADDED LOGO ERROR MESSAGE HERE AS A BACK UP" width="100%" />

This avoids a lot of issues with notifications not being able to render the images from the web via any type of image hosting.

Just make sure that your image quality and size is appropriate as it will lead to an EXTREMELY long code (it will still work but sometimes is slower to render), if you go really high-resolution above what you need to do for the email or Certificate.

Any queries on this approach then please let me know.

Cheers,

Nathan H.

entry.title: FX Difference Posting in Asset Purchase ‚Äì S/4HANA Behavior vs ECC
entry.content:
We would like to highlight an issue observed in our S/4HANA system related to foreign exchange (FX) difference postings during Asset purchases

Background:

  • In ECC, FX differences arising during invoice posting for asset purchases were posted to unrealized gain/loss accounts.
    S/4HANA
  • however, FX differences during invoice posting are currently being posted into the 
    Asset Clearing (TCA) account

    Business Requirement:
    Our business expects FX differences to continue being posted into unrealized gain/loss accounts (as was the case in ECC), rather than being capitalized into the asset account in S/4HANA. 

    Issue:

        • Current S/4HANA behavior: FX differences are posted to the asset account.
        • Desired S4 behavior: FX differences should be posted to unrealized gain/loss accounts
          .
    OBYC  - Gain /Loss already configured as Transactin type KDM
  • Configure How Exchange Rate Differences Are Treated 
    • plain currency type - 10 & Assumed rate - M maintained

Asset purchase using PO  / GR / IR  - Exchange rate difference was GR vs IR posting

in ECC, FX differences are generally posted to unrealized gain/loss accounts during invoice.

Business want this FX difference should post S/4 HANA into unrealized gain/loss accounts also instead of Asset.

Need your support, Thanks !!

entry.title: SAP Self-Billing Cockpit
entry.content:
• SAP Self-Billing Cockpit
  • Supplier Challenges in Self-Billing
  • SAP Self-Billing Cockpit and SAP S/4HANA
  • Key Capabilities
  • Processing Types Supported by SAP Self-Billing Cockpit
  • 1. Self-Billing with Automatic Posting (SBWAP)
  • 2. Self-Billing with Invoice Creation (SBINV)
  • Highlights
  • Solution Highlights (Detailed)
  • 1. Automatic Verification
  • 2. Pre-Processing Simulation
  • 3. Smooth Processing
  • 4. Self-Billing Deviations: A Quick Guide to Price, Quantity, and Tax Management
  • Additional Resources
  • Position in the SAP Landscape
  • Additional Information
  • Blog Post Series for SAP Self-Billing Cockpit

SAP Self-Billing Cockpit

SAP Self-Billing Cockpit (SBC) is a cloud-based application built on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) that simplifies and automates the evaluated receipt settlement (self-billing) process between suppliers and large customers. Designed for seamless integration with SAP S/4HANA, it provides an intelligent validation and processing engine that automates posting, monitoring, and reconciliation of customer-generated self-billing documents.

Self-billing is widely used in industries such as retail, automotive, consumer goods, and wholesale‚Äîwhere customers generate invoices on behalf of suppliers based on goods receipts and pricing agreements.

Supplier Challenges in Self-Billing

Many suppliers still manage incoming self-billing documents manually, which leads to:

  • Delayed processing
  • Frequent errors
  • Undetected discrepancies
  • Higher operational costs
  • Reduced visibility into cash flow

To overcome these challenges, organizations require automated solutions that can reliably identify differences, update financial documents, and support efficient A/R clearing.

SAP Self-Billing Cockpit and SAP S/4HANA

SAP Self-Billing Cockpit is a cloud-native Industry Cloud solution that integrates seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA using OData and SOAP APIs. It delivers a unified and intuitive interface for suppliers to process large volumes of customer-generated self-billing documents with high accuracy and transparency.

Key Capabilities

  • Receive and process buyer transmissions
  • Run verification checks and detect discrepancies
  • Simulate billing results before posting
  • Create or update billing documents and journal entries
  • Prepare data for A/R clearing
  • Monitor the complete self-billing lifecycle in a central cockpit

These capabilities empower billing teams with real-time visibility, streamlined operations, and improved throughput for high-volume processing.

Processing Types Supported by SAP Self-Billing Cockpit

As legal requirements differ across regions, SAP provides two main self-billing applications:

1. Self-Billing with Automatic Posting (SBWAP)

Used in countries where billing documents are automatically created at goods issue.
Common in: Germany, France, and others.

2. Self-Billing with Invoice Creation (SBINV)

Used where suppliers must generate an invoice identical to the buyer‚Äôs self-billing document.
Common in: Spain, Portugal, Czech Republic, and others.

SAP Self-Billing Cockpit supports both processes within a single unified interface.

Self-Billing Cockpit offers automated simulations, straightforward error correction, and one-click execution.

 

 

 

Highlights

  • Automated verification: A central entry page shows the status of all incoming documents and allows quick processing.
  • Pre-processing simulation: Discrepancies are highlighted before posting to prevent unnecessary differential invoices.
  • Smooth processing: Automatically compares incoming documents with internal records and creates required debit/credit memos.

  • Self-Billing Deviations: Quick Guide to Price, Quantity, and Tax Management.

Solution Highlights (Detailed)

1. Automatic Verification

Incoming self-billing documents are validated automatically. A central dashboard provides full transparency into document statuses and allows follow-up actions.

 

 

2. Pre-Processing Simulation

Before posting, SBC simulates the results and highlights potential discrepancies‚Äîhelping prevent incorrect postings and avoiding unwanted differential invoices.

 

 

3. Smooth Processing

The cockpit compares incoming data with internal documents. When differences appear, it creates the required credit or debit memos and updates related journal entries using payment references.

 

 

4. Self-Billing Deviations: A Quick Guide to Price, Quantity, and Tax Management

Use Manage Price Deviations, Manage Quantity Deviations, and Manage Tax Deviations to monitor deviations in price, quantity, and tax, then approve tolerable deviations after checks.

 

 

Additional Resources

  • Promotional Video: Watch here
  • Latest Documentation: Search ‚ÄúSAP Self-Billing Cockpit‚Äù on SAP Help Portal

Position in the SAP Landscape

Component Role

SAP Self-Billing Cockpit (Cloud)Receives and manages customer self-billing data
SAP S/4HANA (On-prem or Cloud)Handles FI/SD posting and downstream processes
SAP BTPPlatform hosting SBC
Cloud ConnectorSecures connectivity between SAP S/4HANA and BTP
OData / SOAP ServicesTechnical communication layer for data exchange

Additional Information

 

  • SAP Self-Billing Cockpit Product Documentation
  • SAP Self-Billing Cockpit on SAP Store

entry.title: Re: Error in Transaction OAYZ ‚Äì Screen Layout Rule for De...
entry.content:
Dear Waris,
This SAP error (AC630) means that for depreciation area 01 and asset class 1027, you either need to assign a valid screen layout rule in customizing or deactivate the depreciation area for that asset class. The reason is transaction OAYZ is used to configure depreciation areas in Asset Accounting. The error message ‚ÄúMaintain screen layout rule for dep.area 01 + asset class 1027 or deactivate it‚Äù (SAP message AC630) occurs when, A depreciation area is active for an asset class, but no screen layout rule is assigned. The system requires either a defined rule or explicit deactivation of the area

To fix the error please follow the steps as mentioned below.
Maintain a Screen Layout Rule
Go to SPRO ‚Üí Financial Accounting ‚Üí Asset Accounting ‚Üí Valuation ‚Üí Depreciation Areas ‚Üí Define Screen Layout Rules. Assign a valid screen layout rule to depreciation area 01 for asset class 1027. This ensures that the system knows which fields are mandatory, optional, or hidden when working with assets in that class.

Deactivate the Depreciation Area
In OAYZ, select asset class 1027. Mark depreciation area 01 as inactive if it should not be used for this asset class. This tells the system to ignore that area for postings related to this asset class. Define a screen layout rule for depreciation area 01 in asset class 1027, or deactivate the area if it‚Äôs not needed. This resolves the OAYZ error and keeps your asset accounting configuration consistent

Hope above steps will resolve your error.

entry.title: Update VA02 ATP simulation schedule line from Z-program problem
entry.content:
Hi experts,

Please tell me how to do with the problem I face below.

The Z-program need to update the new schedule lines as VA02 ATP result in SO item when the user trigger a condition in a user exit.

I can get the VA02 ATP simulation from SD_SALESDOCUMENT_CHANGE

-SCHEDULE_EX.

The problem is if the user set the flag of the complete delivery after a DN created for the partial quantity, and then if I use FMs like SD_BACKORDER_UPDATE or BAPI_SALESDOCUMENT_SAVE or SD_SALESDOCUMENT_CHANGE again, it shows error: "system: item 000200 for schedule line 000300 is in the work area".

There is a FM SD_SALES_DOC_CHECK_ATP can update schedule lines as delay proposal result automaticity, it works fine.

But if there is a item which has complete delivery flag, the Z-program need to choose the complete delivery, not delay proposal.


Is there any suggestion for me?

entry.title: Unable to authenticate backend system from SAP BAS via Cloud Connector ‚Äì ‚ÄúAuthentication incorrect‚Äù
entry.content:
Hello Experts!!

I am trying to consume an on-premise S/4HANA system from SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) using SAP Cloud Connector and a BTP Destination.

The Cloud Connector connection is reachable, and the Destination is visible inside BAS, but when I select the destination (‚ÄúS4H‚Äù) in the SAP Fiori Generator wizard, BAS returns the error:


"Authentication incorrect. Please check the SAP BTP destination authentication configuration."

Even when I remove authentication from the BTP Destination and directly enter credentials in the BAS wizard, the same error appears.

I can successfully log in to the S/4HANA backend via SAP GUI with the same user and password, and the SAP Easy Access screen loads correctly.
However, BAS / Cloud Connector authentication fails.

entry.title: Re: How to bring up the Invoice Reference field in the ap...
entry.content:
To ensure the Invoice Reference field is displayed when expected, consider the following:

  1. Verify that invoices have been split if the field is missing when expected.
  2. Check the alignment between the house bank and payment method. Ensure that they match to prevent the unnecessary absence of the field.

3686252 - Invoice Reference Field is Empty in the app "Manage Payment Requisition" - SAP for Me

entry.title: Blog it Forward - Mino Kato
entry.content:
(The Japanese version follows the English text.) ‚ÄªÊó•Êú¨Ë™ûÁâà„ÅØËã±Ë™û„ÅÆ„ÅÇ„Å®„Å´Á∂ö„Åç„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Introduction

Hello everyone! I received the "Blog it Forward" baton from @sumikko , who organizes community with me, and I am writing this post now. Thank you, Sumikko-san, for this great opportunity! You can read Sumikko-san's post [here] and learn more about the BIF challenge [here].

About Me

My name is Mino Kato. Since "Mino" is a rare name in Japan, people usually call me by my first name rather than a nickname.

I have been working as an SAP consultant in the accounting area for many years. Recently, I have been focusing on projects involving S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (now SAP Cloud ERP), specifically sticking to the "Fit to Standard" approach. I am also an organizer for chillSAP, a local SAP community in Japan, along with Sumikko-san.

Although I am not a developer myself, I love catching up on BTP extension-related and AI-related knowledge that helps users utilize the system more conveniently. This passion motivates my community activities and my multiple participations in SAP TechEd.

My Encounter with SAP

I joined an IT company as a new graduate. After training, the first project I was assigned to along with several colleagues was already in trouble, and we were thrown in as testing personnel. While the business trips and the relationships with the people I worked with are good memories, I suddenly experienced the difficulty of building a system from scratch (or rather, the chaos involving many people when things go wrong).

So, when that project ended and I was given the choice, "Do you want to be involved in Web development or ERP projects next?", I chose ERP without hesitation and went to receive SAP training.

When I saw the SAP system screen (GUI at the time) for the first time, my impression was: "Wow! The buttons are so detailed, and their shapes are perfectly aligned!"

It might sound funny now, but after seeing the chaos, I was moved by the order. Of course, I now know that ERP projects are also difficult and have their own challenges...

Participating in SAP TechEd

Under the mission of "Let's catch up on SAP's new technologies and think of new services" at the company I belonged to at the time, I participated in SAP TechEd for the first time in 2018. I had participated in SAP Inside Track Tokyo in Japan before and felt that TechEd would be interesting. Actually participating, I was able to feel the passion of global engineers and participants from Japan. I thought, "Ah, I love places where we can have these kinds of conversations," which became the trigger for me to actively involve myself in community activities.

Photo from a past TechEd FunRun. I loved these kinds of events too!

Encounter with the Community

During the "Japan Night" at TechEd, I was scouted to speak at SAP Inside Track Tokyo, and presenting on the theme of Design Thinking was a very good experience. I originally loved listening to other people's presentations, but participating as a speaker was an experience that broke down a wall for me. Since that presentation, I think I have become able to jump into various places with lighter footwork.

Long ago, when I started touching SAP, if I ran into something I didn't understand in the finance module, I could only ask seniors at my company or guess the mechanism from SAP Notes information. But now, compared to before, help documents and KBAs are substantial, and we can gain various insights through QA or Blogs in the global community.

And furthermore, it is very stimulating and happy if I can read it in Japanese... Based on such motivation, the SAP Advent Calendar, LT (Lightning Talk) event, and various events of the community "chillSAP" started.

My Favorite Things (Fun Facts)

I love going to the theater. My eyes are glued to living humans unfolding action such as dancing and sword fighting right in front of me. I go to watch ballet, musicals, popular theater, and "2.5-dimensional" plays quite often recently. The opera I watched in between TechEd Berlin the other day was also wonderful. After the pandemic, my spirit of "Let's watch what I want to see live while I can!" has spurred on. I get energy from the stage and turn it into vitality for my daily life.

Sitting in a chair for a long time for theatergoing is bad for the body, but I think doing Yoga regularly helps with that. I like "Ashtanga Yoga," which is quite hard for yoga.

Photo with my teacher Cathy from Hawaii, who I took online classes with during the pandemic, when she came to Japan. (For some reason, she took photos in 3 patterns: vertical, horizontal, and diagonal. This is the diagonal version!)

Answers to BIF Questions

1. If you were 20 again, what would you study?

I might try to get a degree in accounting and get closer to a CPA qualification. In promoting "Fit to Standard," I sometimes feel that having a qualification is easy to understand to be recognized as a specialist in the accounting area. However, learning it after becoming a working adult competes with too many other things I want to learn (English, other foreign languages, SAP and AI technology catch-up), so... But I have no regrets about proceeding to the path of IT by becoming interested in computers while doing experiments and programming in the science department. If I had proceeded to the path of accounting, there is a high possibility that I would not be doing my current job, so I feel it is asking for the moon after all. I will continue to study accounting within the range I can now.

2. What is the most important thing you learned from your parents?

Rather than "learned," it is what they "gave" me. They gave me many books since I was a child, and perhaps due to my original preference, I grew up to be a book lover, which I think is my asset now. I loved experiencing different worlds through picture books and children's books. As I grew up, I read many books including manga, and I was able to know various ways of life and ways of thinking. Being a book lover is also useful when learning new technologies and knowledge now. I love the feeling of my world expanding.

Closing

Thank you for reading this far. Next, I would like to pass the baton to @MikuKawanabe. She is running JSUG's Next Gen Boost community, and I am always stimulated by her powerful activities! I definitely want to know the secret of that energy.

entry.title: Re: Access Build Work Zone, Standard Edition site from SAP EP
entry.content:
Hi @ROHITGERA1,

I only found in the official document that how to make EP a content provider to BWZ, 

3286048 - Enterprise Portal as a Content Provider to SAP BTP - SAP for Me

Enterprise Portal as a Content Provider to SAP BTP | SAP Help Portal

But seems you are doing the opposite way. May I ask which document/guidance you are following? Maybe we need to first make sure the BWZ is a supported content provider in EP, and then look into the authentication side, like here is some common auth issue for BWZ 3203000 - User Authentication for SAP Work Zone - Common Login issues and Configuration requirements - SAP for Me just as a similar reference.

entry.title: To enable task synchronization between Microsoft Outlook and SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C)
entry.content:
Requirement: 
The purpose of this blog is to enable Microsoft Outlook and SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C) task synchronization

Introduction:

This blog post gives a full list of the steps needed to set up task synchronization between Microsoft Outlook and SAP Cloud for Customer (SAP C4C).

Problem Statement:
In order to enable users to manage tasks seamlessly across SAP Cloud for Customer (SAP C4C) and Microsoft Outlook, we needed task synchronization.

Solution:
The SAP Outlook Add-In and the Groupware profile settings can be configured to enable task synchronization between SAP C4C and Microsoft Outlook. By enabling the Task object in both Add-In and Sync settings, users can create and manage tasks directly from Outlook, which will automatically sync with SAP C4C. In this way, tasks can flow between the two platforms bidirectionally.

Benefits:
This method gets rid of the need for users to manually handle tasks in both SAP C4C and Microsoft Outlook. When task synchronization is turned on, tasks made on one platform are automatically shown on the other. This cuts down on duplication and makes it easier to keep track of tasks. It makes users' jobs easier and cuts down on the work needed to keep systems consistent.

Implementation Steps:
STEP 1:
Navigate to SAP C4C E-Mail Integration ‚Üí Groupware Settings ‚Üí Profile, then select the profile for which task synchronization needs to be enabled (e.g., Demo Profile).

STEP 2:
Navigate to the Add-In Settings ‚Üí Click the 'Manage Object' button ‚Üí Search for 'Tasks' and click 'Apply'.

STEP 3:
Now the Task object will be available in Add-In Settings. Click the dropdown and configure the Basic View, Searching and Sorting, and Detailed View columns as needed. Then, click 'Save'.

STEP 4:
Now navigate to Sync Settings and turn on the toggle for the Task object. If you want attachments to be synced or prefer to keep tasks read-only, enable the respective toggles. Set the record limit as needed, and click 'Save'.

STEP 5:
If the profile is already assigned to users also click on apply profile for all users to update the changes to the users profile

STEP 6:
Now open Outlook and launch the SAP Add-In. Click the '+' icon to create a new task.

STEP 7:
Fill in all the required information and click 'Save' to create the task.

STEP 8:
Once the task is created, you will be able to see it in the To-Do list.
Note: The task will not appear in the Outlook calendar, it will only be available in the To-Do list.

STEP 9:
Now navigate to C4C, and you will be able to see the task created in the C4C calendar.
Note: Tasks created from Outlook will be synced to the C4C calendar, and tasks created in C4C will be synced to the Outlook To-Do list.

STEP 10:
Now add an attachment to the task from C4C. The attachment will be synced to Outlook.
Note: Attachments added in C4C will sync to Outlook, but attachments added in Outlook will not sync back to C4C.

STEP 11:
Once the task is completed, it will appear at the end of the To-Do list under the 'Completed' section.

Conclusion:
This Blog outlines the process of creating and synchronizing tasks between Outlook and SAP C4C, making task management easier for users. By following these steps, users can ensure seamless integration and improved efficiency.

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing Production Process Quality ‚Äî Blog Series, Part 1
entry.content:
Purpose of this series

This three-part series distils best practices from SAP Digital Manufacturing implementation projects to raise the quality, maintainability, and speed of your Production Process Designs (PPDs):

  • Part 1 (this post): Foundations, naming conventions, and design discipline (dry but essential).
  • Part 2: Structuring production processes, designing scalable machine integrations and choosing the right feature for the job (data storage, triggers, services).
  • Part 3: Bits and pieces that may change with DM releases (transport options, evolving patterns, practical tips). This, in the end, will be a collector for smaller blogs on specific Production Process topics that come up over time.

 

Why structure and discipline matter

Well-structured PPDs accelerate delivery, lower risk, and make operations easier:

  • Support teamwork: Clear separation of responsibilities reduces coordination effort and enables ownership.
  • Fast, stable deployments: Smart structuring avoids long deployments and timeouts and helps you stay within environment limits.
  • Easier imports/transports to PROD: Encapsulating asset interactions simplifies re-imports and limits manual adaptations.
  • Easy operation: Better understandability, maintainability, and testability; changes are confined to small, well-defined designs.

 

Criticality Levels

This guide utilizes criticality levels to strike a balance between flexibility and discipline. We want teams to move fast: use the Production Process Designer and its features to build quick prototypes, learn, and iterate. Guidelines should not block experimentation. At the same time, productive usage benefits from clear standards so designs are safe, maintainable, and operable (see ‚ÄúWhy structure and discipline matter‚Äù). Treat the guideline list below as a starting point, not a mandate. Discuss it with your project team, decide which points are essential for your context, and classify each as Must, Should, or Could.

Please also utilize the comment section to share additional guidelines you believe are essential for developing high-quality production processes.

 

General production process design guidelines

Must:

  • Apply your agreed naming convention consistently across designs, processes, script tasks, variables, and interfaces.
  • Apply error handling. The details may be found in the section on error handling.
  • Document all external calls to DM APIs (like published PPs and public APIs) to be able to evaluate the impact of API changes more easily. For the standard APIs this deprecation policy is leading including its exceptions https://help.sap.com/docs/business-accelerator-hub/sap-business-accelerator-hub/sap-api-deprecation-policy
  • Before you start working on a production process that should go live, write a specification describing what the process should do and which APIs are needed to achieve this. The specification can be the basis for your documentation.
  • Don‚Äôt rely on the order of lists of API responses e.g. custom fields, operations, BOM-items. Either search for what you need or sort the list in a script task before accessing.
    Example: It could be tempting to access a custom field for the serial number of a component like this customData[0].value, as the first one was always the serial number field. Instead, loop over all custom data fields, check which attribute is the serial number, and then read the value of this item.
  • Keep logic simple: avoid deeply nested or mixed loops; keep subprocess hierarchies shallow; prefer clear, linear flows.
    The production process designer allows you to design ‚Äúspaghetti code‚Äù loops, and you should avoid this as you would in a modern programming language.
  • Don‚Äôt use MDOs in Processes, which can cause production downtime or write the wrong data if data is not retrieved in time. It might take some time until the data is available/synchronized to the MDOs. If your process is robust to use older versions of the data or you are sure enough time has passed for replication, you still might use MDOs in your Production Process Design.
  • Check Note 3379404 for the current cloud process restrictions e.g. max loop cycles, request timeouts, script task memory, etc.
  • Replace deprecated APIs in time. One of the pieces we plan for part 3 of the series is how to approach replacing deprecated APIs. It will be linked here later on.

Should:

  • Limit design size to around 20 processes per design. Larger designs tend to deploy slowly and are riskier to import to PROD.
  • Use a common modelling direction. E.g. model left to right (priority 1) and top to bottom (priority 2). Only loops should break this direction, which makes it easier to spot them when debugging production processes after some time has passed. Avoid intersecting flows, if possible, to allow for better readability.
  • Read API documentation carefully and perform API-level tests to confirm behavior matches your assumptions.
  • Reference the production process documentation in the process header, which explains the purpose, inputs & outputs, external calls, the responsible person, and the DM version it was implemented in.
    Alternatively, the annotation function is available, so you can comment the elements with useful information on the process.
  • Clean up unused production processes and PODs regularly. This is mainly in the QUAL landscape (if you delete PPs which are deployed, they will still be available in the archived status)
  • With new releases, the standard functions' scope will grow. Regularly check if workarounds with custom fields and other extensions are still needed.

Could:

  • Use process variables to pass information created across loop iterations or different condition branches to subsequent logic.

 

Naming conventions

The naming convention should help maintain consistency between the different designs you create and support understandability when analyzing the production processes.

This naming convention mostly uses CamelCase. However, if you favor other styles, just go for it. Consistency matters.

Must:

  • Use speaking names for all objects (designs, processes, subprocesses, variables, indicators, services). This is the most important naming rule of them all, so don‚Äôt use indicator1, var2, etc.
  • Rename each script task to a concise summary of its purpose in CamelCase.
  • Do not reuse the same name for local variables in a script and a process variable (avoid unintended shadowing).
  • Avoid key names in variable names.

Suggested conventions:

  • Design name
    • <Scope>_<Description>
    • E.g. Generic_Staging, P100_MachineIntegration
  • Process name
    • <NameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. ChecksBeforeSFCComplete
  • Script task name
    • <NameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. CalcStagingRequestItems
  • Process inputs
    • <nameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. orderStatus
  • Process outputs
    • <nameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. batchNumber
  • Process variables
    • p<NameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. pSFCIterator
  • Global variables
    • g<NameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. gPartsCounter
  • Script tasks input variables
    • in<NameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. inOrderNumber
  • Script tasks output variables
    • out<NameInCamelCase>
    • E.g. outOrderNumber

 

Script Tasks

Script tasks are where most project-specific logic is hidden. They connect services, indicators, and control elements. Clear names, concise intent comments, and lightweight logging make scripts easier to understand, test, and operate.  

In general, you can consider them as code snippets, so everything you know about code quality also applies here. These are just a couple of specific points we find useful for DM projects.

MUST:

  • Rename the script task to a summary of its purpose ‚Üí NameInCamelCase
  • Use one comment at the beginning of the script to describe its purpose.

SHOULD:

  • Add additional comments in difficult places or where you want to explain your intent.
  • Discuss input and output parameters and their purpose for more complex script tasks.
  • Delete out commented code from script task before moving them to production.
  • Use .toISOString() in a script task to create DM conform timestamps. Schema: ‚ÄúYYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.SSSZ‚Äù
  • Don‚Äôt use try catch statements in script tasks if you don‚Äôt have a well-tested catch statement which makes sense and works for all cases. If you just use a try catch block to ‚Äúcatch them all‚Äù runtime errors at production will be very difficult to spot.

COULD:

  • Introduce some logging within the script if the script tasks get very complex.
  • Use an IDE for script task development.

This could be an example of the comment at the beginning of the script task.

 

Error handling principles

Production Processes rely on external calls, which could return error codes or suffer from temporary unavailability. By anticipating this during the design, smaller issues can be covered, and robustness will increase.

MUST:

  • Configure Automatic Retries to increase robustness. Defaults you can start with:
    • GET APIs: retry on all errors ‚Äî 5 attempts, 3-second interval.
    • POST/PUT/DELETE APIs: retry on 408, 429, 500, 502, 503, 504 ‚Äî 5 attempts, 3-second interval.
  • Consider Idempotency. Idempotency is a property of operations or API requests that ensures repeating the operation multiple times produces the same result as executing it once. Only a few APIs support this yet, check the details in SAP Note 3375209
  • Use Custom Error Codes to communicate with users or the calling process. If none is set, the Production Process returns HTTP500. Downstream processes can catch and branch on Custom Error Codes, when you have multiple codes, add a condition to handle them differently.
  • Hint: Consider IMD (Integration Message Dashboard) automatic retries for message-based integrations.

SHOULD:

  • Tune retry counts/intervals to the business scenario: increase for critical paths, lower for non-critical paths to prioritize performance.
  • Use SAP Cloud ALM to monitor Production Processes and Integration Messages in production.

COULD:

  • Use Error Catches to handle specific errors when it‚Äôs simpler to catch them than to check the state before. Example: call startSFC() and catch 409 ‚Äúalready started,‚Äù then treat it as a no-op success.

 

What‚Äôs next in the series

  • Part 2: Structuring production processes, designing machine integrations and choosing the right feature for the job (data storage, triggers, services).
  • Part 3: Bits and pieces that may change with DM releases (transport options, evolving patterns, practical tips). This, in the end, could also be a collector for smaller blogs on specific Production Process topics that come up over time.

 

Have fun designing your production processes.

@lukas_furmanek  and @Kevin_Hunter1

Our query is
Do we have any way to suppress Health Monitoring Alerts in Cloud ALM during Planned Downtime of managed systems? (similar to what we have in Focused Run and Solution Manager)

Thanks,




Manually selected component: SV-CLM-OP-HM

entry.title: Re: How to suppress Health Monitoring Alerts in Cloud ALM...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

"Business Service Management" has feature to Integration with SAP Cloud ALM monitoring, Health Monitoring will suppress event actions (create alert, send mail, create ticket, start operation flow) during maintenances and disruptions.

you could refer to the following guide for further info regarding "Suppressing Health Monitoring Alerts in Cloud ALM during Planned Downtime":

https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal/business-service-management.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/business-service-management

Please get back to us when you have further inquiry.

 

Best Regards,

Sunny

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: One step after the other - Long-distance hiking
entry.content:
From one extreme hobby to another: While rileyrainey enjoys jumping down from huge heights, I love hiking the extra mile. Or better said: hiking over thousands of kilometers, one day after another, one step at a time. I am happy to take on the baton in the SAP  Community Hobbies series and introduce my passion of long-distance hiking to you. 

Who I am?

Hi! I am Jan Rumig from Germany, a Chief Development Architect in the SAP Business Technology Platform. As a contrast to my daily office hours, I spend most of my leisure time with hiking, reading about hiking and taking pictures of our beautiful nature while hiking. One could say I breathe hiking. Since recently, I also found passion in standing in front of big audiences and talk about my adventures.

How my love for hiking began

I wasn‚Äôt even born yet when my parents first took me to the mountains. It all began back then in Ramsau am Dachstein, where I spent several weeks each year with my family. During my teenage years, I went on my first solo hikes there. Later, as a young adult, I started to intensify this passion - spending one or two weeks a year in mountain regions, always with a fixed base. At that time, I already had the desire to explore new and more distant regions, but often I lacked hiking companions, and I didn‚Äôt quite have the courage to set out on my own.

First Solo Adventures: Portugal, the Balkans, and Beyond

Everything changed after a painful breakup. From that moment on, there was no holding back. My first solo hike took me to the Rota Vicentina, the Fishermen‚Äôs Trail in Portugal - one of the most beautiful coastal hikes in the world. Many more regions followed: Serbia, Romania, Ukraine, the Peaks of the Balkans Trail, Colombia, and several others. I was infected with hiking fever. The more I saw and experienced, the more I wanted to discover. Between trips to faraway countries, I explored the Alps. And even on weekends, I felt the urge to head outdoors. Luckily, I live close to wonderful hiking regions - the Odenwald, the Palatinate, or the Black Forest are my weekly playgrounds.

üéßSome details of the Peaks of the Balkans, I discussed in a podcast, in German only: Wanderwach & Kaffee.

Beautiful coastline on the Rota Vicentina

Gjeravica, highest mountain of Cosovo

Inspiration from New Zealand: Te Araroa

But deep down, I had always carried an unfulfilled desire to experience a truly long and demanding adventure. At first, my own inner doubts held me back: You won‚Äôt manage this, something could happen to you‚Ä¶ You can still do such an adventure at a later point in time. Then, in 2022, two colleagues of mine passed away unexpectedly. It was a harsh reminder not to postpone life. I asked my boss whether I could take six months off. Luckily, I had accumulated 162 vacation days over the years. My leave was approved. Some years earlier, I had heard of the Te Araroa in New Zealand - 3,000 km through breathtaking landscapes. So, over the turn of the year 2023/2024, I set off for New Zealand. The Te Araroa is considered one of the toughest long-distance trails in the world - and for good reason. While it is fully marked, it often leads through pathless terrain. In total, I had to ford around 100 rivers, some of them chest-deep. Much of the forest felt like jungle, and the ‚Äútrail‚Äù was often nothing more than a mudfest. Yet, perhaps because of these challenges, it became an unforgettable experience that profoundly changed me and my outlook on life. And ‚Äúunfortunately,‚Äù it also sparked an insatiable appetite for long-distance hiking and adventure. I decided then and there to take more extended breaks in the future, balancing my career with my passion for the outdoors.

üéßPodcast epiode about all the details of my hike through New Zealand, in German only: Holy Sheep Neuseeland. 

Typical New Zealand forestSunrise over the Richmond RangesJan above Lake ConstanceRainbow over mountain hutEnd of Te Araroa trail in Bluff

Discovering my homeland

No sooner had one adventure ended than I wanted to plan the next. But after those long-haul flights to New Zealand, I didn‚Äôt want to put such a strain on the environment again. That‚Äôs when everything came together: during my trek in New Zealand, I listened to a podcast where Soulboy spoke about the creation of the North South Trail (NST). From that moment, a seed was planted: Wouldn‚Äôt it be wonderful to explore my own homeland on foot? Many of the trails that make up the NST had already been on my personal wish list for some time. And while on the Te Araroa I was just one of about 4,000 hikers per year, only around 30 verified hikers had completed the NST in its entirety so far. So, my decision was clear: in 2025, I would set out to hike the NST.
What were my expectations for the trail? I was well aware that the wilderness experience of New Zealand couldn‚Äôt be replicated in Germany - and I wasn‚Äôt looking for that. Instead, I wanted to get to know my homeland step by step, meter by meter, discovering its many facets from north to south. A few examples: the landscape begins flat as a pancake in the north and gradually grows more mountainous as you move south. Or take food: up north it‚Äôs Mettbr√∂tchen for breakfast or giant Rumkugeln from the bakery, in the Palatinate it‚Äôs Saumagen, and in the south you‚Äôre rewarded with Kaiserschmarrn. And I was eager to explore regions I‚Äôd never visited before, many of which had long been on my list. On its 3,700 kilometers, the North South Trail connects 36 certified trails leading through 30 national parks.
People often ask me which parts of the North South Trail were my favorites. Uff, that‚Äôs a tough question. Every region has something exciting to offer, and I honestly can‚Äôt narrow it down to just one. The Saar-Hunsr√ºck-Steig fascinated me because it‚Äôs so diverse and offers a little bit of everything: narrow singletracks, streams, beautiful forests, castles, and more. The Palatinate Wine Trail felt special because it‚Äôs close to my home, so I felt a sense of familiarity there - and the Palatinate people are simply warm-hearted folks. Even in the Black Forest, where I had plenty of bad weather, there were memorable sections - especially the famous Schluchtensteig. But if I had to pick what touched me the most, it‚Äôs always the high mountains. That‚Äôs why the Nagelfluhkette near the end of the trail truly stole my heart.

üéßSome stories and more details of my walk through Germany can be found in this podcast episode, in German only: Off the Path.

Deer under treesRed KitePalatinate forestMountain in cloudsJan above Oberstdorf valleyMost southern point of Germany: Haldenwanger Eck

 

What is so fascinating in long-distance hiking

As I indicated already before, I love being outdoors, experiencing all sensory impulses from nature and watching and photographing all the beauty out there. But these reasons are not specific to long-distance hiking. What makes long distances special: you have to carry all your stuff on your back, most of the times including a tent and cooking equipment. On my hike through Germany I carried a total weight of around 18 kg without water. While hiking, you reduce yourself to the most minimal needs. As a famous female German hiker, Christine Th√ºrmer, says: every day you only focus on walk, sleep, eat, repeat. If you then get a shower after several days or you buy a chocolate bar, these small things make you really, really happy.

üéß More details about the fascination of long-distance hiking, I discussed in a podcast episode, in German only: Frei Raus. 

All my stuff for a long distance hike

Special support: Trail Angels üëº

Have you ever heard about trail angels? For long-distance hikers these are true angels. These are usually private individuals that support hikers along the trail with free food or a chance for an overnight sleeping opportunity. On my trip through Germany, I stayed at 25 trail angels. Most of these stays were much better than any hotel. Sometimes there was a delicious dinner, a free bed and a rich breakfast. As most of them are also outdoorsy, I got new inspirations for future adventures. These encounters with foreign people is exactly what's missing in today's world: love towards humans that you don't know.

Reaching the final signpost

Although I enjoy every minute of my walks, it is such a wonderful feeling when you reach the final signpost at the end of your long trail. All the tension falls apart and you feel deeply relieved. I am always really proud of what I achieved with my body. Our body is the most fascinating thing. Once accommodated, it carries you everywhere like a machine. We have to cherish all of it and take care about our health. My proudest moment so far was achieving the North South Trail in Fastest known time. For the 3,700 km I only needed 96 hiking days + 2 rest days.

Everybody can do it

You have doubts if you can do the same? Don't worry. The good news is: you can. Before you start on a long hike, do some test hikes. First maybe start with a single days, then a weekender, followed by multiple days. If you feel comfortable, go for something longer. And when the day comes, the important thing is, start slowly and give your body the time it needs to accommodate to the efforts. Day by day you will feel getting stronger and more endurable. The worst thing you can do is to never start. Always remember that our life is limited. Better regret the things you've done than the things you haven't done. 

What will be next?

So, am I done with long-distance hiking now? Absolutely not - quite the opposite. The big question is simply: what‚Äôs next? For now, I think I‚Äôll choose something a little shorter. Current favorites include the High Scardus Trail through North Macedonia, Kosovo, and Albania, the Lycian Way in Turkey, or perhaps the GR20 on Corsica as an add-on. But who knows - maybe something entirely different will come my way.
Besides hiking, I discovered another related hobby: talking about my adventures. So I take my pictures and videos, convert them into visually attractive multi-vision shows, add stories and present them in front of big audiences. Let's connect if you see a chance for me to present my adventures somewhere close by to you. üòä

üéü  For readers based in Germany around Heidelberg, there is the perfect opportunity to listen first-hand about my hike through New Zealand, I will be a speaker at the wonderful Wunderwelten Festival on January 3rd.  

One of my talks about the hike through New Zealand

 

Want to know more?

You also want to start hiking? There are a lot of outdoor portals where you can easily find beautiful hikes around the place where you live. Just search for tours in your region in your favorite search engine. Additionally, contact me, I might have some proposals. üòá

You became curious to learn more about my hikes?

  • You find a lot of pictures and daily reports of my travels on my Instagram account. 
  • You can access all my hikes on Komoot.

Coming up next

I am happy to pass the baton to Marika who is introducing her hobbies singing and theatre to us. In addition she engages in meaningful volunteer work. Stay tuned!
